image.altText: Mariona Caldentey of Spain controls the ball against Lucy Bronze of England during the FIFA Women's World Cup final.

items.synopsis: A new name will be inscribed on the FIFA Women's World Cup trophy as Spain and England meet in the final at Stadium Australia in Sydney. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: England and Spain meet in the World Cup final at Stadium Australia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Olga Carmona with a fierce, low strike into the bottom corner! It came from a turnover after Lucy Bronze went off on a mazy run from right back into the centre of the field. Spain won the ball and instantly switched play to that now under-staffed left side for Spain to attack. Caldentey laid the ball wide to Carmona, whose low shot was sensational. Accurate. Powerful. Brilliant opener for Spain.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 29' GOAL SPAIN!

children.content: Olga Carmona with a fierce, low strike into the bottom corner!
It came from a turnover after Lucy Bronze went off on a mazy run from right back into the centre of the field.
Spain won the ball and instantly switched play to that now under-staffed left side for Spain to attack.
Caldentey laid the ball wide to Carmona, whose low shot was sensational. Accurate. Powerful. Brilliant opener for Spain.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So close to the opener for Lauren Hemp! Lovely football to get the ball into the penalty area, Rachel Daly lays the ball off to Hemp, who curls a shot towards the top corner but just a fraction too high and the ball cannons back off the bar!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 16' ENGLAND HITS THE CROSSBAR!

children.content: So close to the opener for Lauren Hemp!

Lovely football to get the ball into the penalty area, Rachel Daly lays the ball off to Hemp, who curls a shot towards the top corner but just a fraction too high and the ball cannons back off the bar!

image.altText: Sam Kerr with Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk and a framed photo of the team

items.synopsis: The Matildas have certainly won Australia over, with one capital city gifting the record-breaking team its keys to the city.

title.children: Investment in women's and girl's sport to triple following the Matildas' record-breaking performance

image.altText: Rocket launching into sky

items.synopsis: Russia's national space agency says it lost contact with the unmanned craft shortly after a problem occurred as it was shunted into pre-landing orbit.

title.children: Russia's Luna-25 spacecraft crashes into Moon in uncontrolled orbit

image.altText: woman looking down

items.synopsis: The rising costs of living are increasing pressure on some international students to make difficult choices, such as paying for rent instead of mental health appointments.

title.children: Evania cannot afford mental health care as she is paying $470 a week for a room with 'big rats' and 'cockroaches'

image.altText: Flames surround homes on Forbes St in Hawthorne, Brisbane

items.synopsis: A Brisbane home was "destroyed" by fire after a woman noticed smoke coming from the back of her dishwasher.

title.children: 'He was fully singed': 66-year-old man in critical condition after fire destroys home

items.synopsis: Health, NDIS and defence among five areas set to account for half of government spend by 2063.

title.children: NDIS and defence among main federal government spending pressures in next 40 years

image.altText: A man wearing a suit

items.synopsis: Media personality Andrew O'Keefe will remain behind bars after he was arrested in Sydney for allegedly contravening an apprehended violence order.

image.altText: Chairlift accident

title.children: 'Who's meant to clean the kitchen? Football club pulls newsletter after controversial opinion piece

image.altText: Vladimir Putin with a slight smile on his face, with a row of men in naval uniforms lined up behind him

image.altText: Baby Harrison McLaren with dad Christopher, mum Jessica and sister Lara

items.synopsis: Harry had a condition known medically as gastroschisis — a hole in his abdominal wall.

title.children: Jessica was 20 weeks pregnant when she learned her baby's organs were growing outside his body. He's now 'close to crawling'

image.altText: Some Indigenous people at a rodeo.

image.altText: Air Force aircrafts take part in military drills by the Eastern Theatre Command of China's People's Liberation Army.

title.children: Taiwan says 25 Chinese military planes crossed Taiwan Strait median line

items.synopsis: SA Police say investigators believe the fire, which broke out in the early hours of this morning, was deliberately lit.

image.altText: Woman in green shirt and black puffer standing next to orange wall

items.synopsis: The Canadian province is in a state of emergency as forest fires around the country's west intensify.

title.children: 'Difficult days ahead' for British Columbians as 35,000 flee fires

image.altText: A girl with black hair sits in the tray of a ute with green sandbags

items.synopsis: Forecasters expect the storm to enter the history books as the first tropical storm to hit Southern California in 84 years, and bring along flash floods, mudslides, isolated tornadoes, high winds and widespread power outages.

image.altText: three forks and their shadows on a sea green background

image.altText: A close-up view of a white plastic rapid antigen test for COVID-19 held by hands in blue surgical gloves.

title.children: What we know about the new COVID strain nicknamed after an asteroid

image.altText: A close up of a pair of hands scooping up water

title.children: Residents of this remote town were missing the 'basic human right' of clean drinking water, until last month

image.altText: A woman smiles next to a range of Barbie dolls in boxes.

items.synopsis: With only 20 years of seriously collecting the dolls under her belt, Alison Burton has been hawkishly watching the Barbie market as their value keeps rising.

title.children: Alison shares her Brisbane home with 150 extremely rare Barbie dolls

image.altText: A soccer player wearing blue and light green leans on her knees with an Australian flag in the background

items.synopsis: For 96 gruelling minutes, they tried to make history on the pitch. But for these exhausted Matildas, their race was already run.

title.children: Matildas' loss to Sweden revealed a team that had already given everything

image.altText: Philip Lowe and Michele Bullock August 2023

items.synopsis: What stories should economics journalists tell? Who are they writing for? asks Gareth Hutchens

title.children: What is the point of economics journalism?

title.children: After weeks of love and care, this once-starved Tawaki penguin is heading home to New Zealand

image.altText: A composite of two men looking away from the camera

items.synopsis: This is not the first time prosthetic noses have popped up on screen and caused controversies towards the Jewish community.

title.children: Bradley Cooper has been accused of 'Jewface' over his new movie — here's what that means

image.altText: A woman staring into the distance while treading water with a number of people

items.synopsis: Fly-fishing is more than just a pastime for Monica Tonner — it's a beautiful sport with deeply personal connections with her late father.

title.children: Dad's memory drives daughter's epic swim to help cancer patients find peace

image.altText: A close up of a yellow beehive-like flower which is being squeezed by a hand, with clear juice coming out of it.

items.synopsis: Lovers of Australian-grown tropical flowers could have trouble finding them as an usually rainy dry season has put Queensland growers two months behind schedule.

title.children: Tropical flower supply looking tight as rain dampens the north's dry season

image.altText: A woman with bleached blonde hair looks off into the distance.

items.synopsis: Suicidal, anorexic and struggling with a methamphetamine addiction, Chrissy Grieve thought the world was against her. Now, the mother-of-six is helping other vulnerable people realise they are not alone.

title.children: Chrissy Grieve's son told her if she wanted to be a grandma, she had to get clean. For her, it was a turning point

image.altText: A runner falls flat on her face while her opponent crosses the finish line.

items.synopsis: Two Dutch runners fall over just metres from victory in two different races, while Rohan Browning makes it into the 100m semifinal in Budapest.

title.children: Double disaster for Dutch as two runners fall at the finish, while Browning ends 28-year Australian drought

image.altText: Jason Horne-Francis holds his arms out and smiles in the direction of the crowd

items.synopsis: Port Adelaide and Melbourne will have double-chances in September as wins over Fremantle and Hawthorn lock in a top-four finish, but West Coast's stunning upset of the Western Bulldogs blows the finals race wide open.

title.children: Power, Demons lock in top-four finishes, but shock Eagles win rocks Bulldogs' finals dream

image.altText: A before and after shot of a social media app changing the shape of a woman's body

items.synopsis: People have been aware of photoshopped images in magazines and on social media for years, but a new study has found young women are less likely to believe that videos can also be edited.

title.children: Undetectable social media filters allowing women to change their bodies in videos

image.altText: A Newcastle Knights NRLW player kicks a conversion from the tee against the Brisbane Broncos.

items.synopsis: Reigning NRLW premier Newcastle celebrates a remarkable comeback 22-20 win over Brisbane that went down to the last play of the match, while third-placed Canberra repels a spirited Parramatta line-up to win 28-22.

title.children: Knights pip Broncos with clutch full-time conversion, Raiders hold off plucky Eels

image.altText: Goalpost

items.synopsis: AFL boss Gillon McLachlan says last night's controversial 'behind' call in Adelaide's loss to Sydney would have been overturned if it had been reviewed, in what he called a "human mistake".

title.children: 'It would have been overturned': AFL boss says umpire got it wrong in crucial 'behind' call in Crows game

image.altText: Image of thylacine yawning with colours blue, green and sany brown d added.

items.synopsis: Scientists say they can bring the extinct thylacine back from the dead within a decade, but does anybody want them to? The resounding answer to an ABC survey is "Yes".

title.children: Should the thylacine be brought back to life? Here's how you responded
